description: A historic downtown area dating back to the 11th century, known for its maze of narrow streets, traditional tube houses, and the famous 36 Old Streets, each historically dedicated to a specific craft or trade. The area serves as Hanoi's economic and cultural hub, blending centuries of history with vibrant modern urban life.
highlights: The 36 Old Streets - each street historically specialized in one craft (silver, silk, paper, etc.)
Night Market on weekends (Friday-Sunday, 6 PM to midnight) with pedestrian-only streets
Ta Hien Street (Beer Street) - the pulse of Bia Hoi drinking tradition
Dong Xuan Market - Hanoi's largest market established in 1889
Traditional tube houses - unique narrow architecture from Nguyen dynasty
French colonial architecture throughout the district
Water Puppet Show at Thang Long Theatre
tips: Set aside 3-4 hours for a leisurely exploration, or split visits over 2-3 days
Walk on the narrow roads and dodge motorbikes - it's part of the authentic experience
Consider taking a cyclo ride to navigate the hustle and bustle comfortably
Visit the weekend Night Market for a pedestrian-friendly experience
Sample street food throughout the district
The area is generally very safe, but keep normal precautions against pickpocketing
Best experienced by simply walking and observing the life around you
vibe: Chaotic yet captivating, the Old Quarter overwhelms first-time visitors with its endless stream of motorbikes, hole-in-the-wall market stalls, and cramped footpaths. Yet beneath the frenetic energy lies authentic Vietnamese culture - the clinking glasses at Beer Street, the hum of happy chatter, and centuries of craftsmanship. It's where Hanoi's soul truly lives, offering an unfiltered glimpse into daily life where tradition meets modernity in beautiful chaos.
